thread.title: Lynch leads Lady Indians to finals with no-hitter
thread.title_full: Lynch leads Lady Indians to finals with no-hitter

title: Lynch leads Lady Indians to finals with no-hitter
text:
Comments Lynch 
East Coweta softball coach Franklin DeLoach knows having three pitchers on his roster is a luxury that most opponents struggle to match. 
And while DeLoach has had his own difficulties trying to rotate between his trio of ace s , Wednesday's choice couldn't have been better. 
Putting the ball in the hands of freshma n Kelley Lynch against rival Newnan with a trip to the Region 3- championship game at stake and Mississippi State head coach Vann Stuedeman in attendance in Sharpsburg, Lynch performed like a future SEC star in the making. 
The Lady Indians ninth grader came through with a no-hitter, striking out 12, and walking just three en route to an 8-0 victory over the Lady Cougars in a game called after five innings. 
'She did an outstanding job for us out there,' DeLoach said of Lynch, whose older sister Katey hit a grand slam in last year's tournament semifinal win over Newnan. 'She doesn't play like a freshman or act like a freshman.' 
The victory put the Lady Indians into tonight's 6:30 p.m., championship while awaiting the winner of a third meeting this season between Newnan and South Cobb. The Lady Cougars, who evened up their record with South Cobb in Tuesday's 5-4 tournament win, can clinch home field for the first round of the Class state playoffs with a victory in today's 4:30 p.m., while also setting up a rematch with East Coweta. 
Two victories by Newnan would set up a deciding game with the Lady Indians as the program did in 2013. East Coweta didn't let things get that far last fall, winning the title in its first try. 
'We know whoever we play will have to be ready,' DeLoach said. 'Our goal is to win the first game. If it goes to a second game, momentum can do crazy things. 
DeLoach can now turn to veteran pitcher Morgan Goree with lefty Rachel Vaughan also available. 
Despite her age, Lynch is used to performing in big games, having played in ASA Nationals for four consecutive years at the travel level. In Tuesday's victory over Westlake she hit two homers, including one that banged off the scoreboard. 
She started Wednesday's effort from the circle by striking out the side in the first inning. Despite allowing one of her three walks to lead off the second, Lynch again rebounded with three more strikeouts. 
Lynch leads an up-and-coming nucleus that included eight eighth-graders playing with the junior varsity, a team that lost just one game this season. 
But first, she has an opportunity to help lead this year's varsity squad back to the Class Elite 8 in Columbus. 
'It's exciting to be part of the varsity as a freshman,' she said. 'I have really great teammates. Olivia (Davis) is a great catcher and she has really helped me. Morgan and Rachel have been great too. My teammates have really helped.' 
East Coweta's offense also belted 10 hits. 
Leadoff hitter Mekhia Freeman and Madison Carter led the way with two RBIs each. 
Freeman's triple in the fifth inning accounted for both of her RBIs and put ended the game by the 8-0 mercy rule. 
The Lady Indians scored two runs in the first and second, one in the third and three in the fifth to secure the victory. 
Davis, Dani Morgan and Jamie Vitale had RBIs for the Lady Indians. 
Newnan chances to score were limited with just three runners reaching because of walks, In addition to Shakerra Geter's walk in the second, Hannah Scarbrough worked the count full before drawing a pass in the third inning to become the Lady Cougars second base runner of the game. 
But East Coweta retired the next six batters, including four by strikeout. Newnan's Katelin Richardson drew a leadoff walk in the fifth to become the Lady Cougars' final base runner. 
Newnan sophomore pitcher Addie Andrews struck out one and walked one in the loss, retiring East Coweta's side in order in the fourth. 
East Coweta increased the lead to 4-0 in the second after Lindsey Warren and Davis were hit by pitchers. Both runners scored on Madison Carter's double. 
The Lady Indians pushed one runner across the plate in the third after Ashlynn Gunter, Warren, and Vitale singled with two outs. Davis kept the inning alive with her team's fourth-straight hit to plate Gunter. 
East Coweta put the game away in the fifth when Vitale knocked in Vaughan with a sacrifice fly and Freeman ripped a two-run triple to close the game by mercy rule. 
LADY INDIANS 8, LADY COUGARS 0 
NEWNAN 000 00 - 0 0 1 
EAST COWETA 221 03 - 8 10 0 
WP - Kelley Lynch
